p: One of the key challenges facing humanity today is climate change. The Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC 2007, 2010) indicates that the energy balance within the Earth’s climate system has been altered, and this has resulted in significant changes in national, regional and world climate. IPCC ( 2007) has observed increases in average air and ocean temperatures, widespread melting of snow and ice, and rising global average sea level. In Zimbabwe, climate change presents risks to lives and livelihoods at the individual level and to the economy, and the livelihoods of the poor are highly vulnerable to climate change because of heavy reliance on rain-fed agriculture (Brown 2011). Zimbabwe has not been spared from the effects of climate change (Downing 1991). The country’s annual mean surface temperature has warmed by about 0.4 °C from 1900 to 2000 (Chigwada 2009). The occurrence and amount of rainfall is becoming increasingly uncertain and the two decades from 1980 have witnessed a trend towards reduced rainfall or heavy rainfall and drought occurring in the same season (GoZ-UNDP/GEF 2009).
